===Africa=== There are important mangrove swamps in [[Kenya]], [[Tanzania]], Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and [[Madagascar]], with the latter even admixing at the coastal verge with [[Madagascar dry deciduous forests|dry deciduous forests]].
Nigeria has Africa's largest mangrove concentration, spanning 36,000 km<sup>2</sup>. Oil spills and leaks have destroyed many in the last 50 years, damaging the local fishing economy and water quality.<ref name="Geographic">{{Cite journal |author=O'Neill, Tom |date=February 2007 |title=Curse of the Black Gold: Hope and betrayal in the Niger Delta |journal=National Geographic |volume=211 |issue=2 |pages=88–117 |url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2007/02/nigerian-oil/oneill-text/1 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101205015251/http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2007/02/nigerian-oil/oneill-text/1 |archivedate=5 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Along the coast of the [[Red Sea]], both on the [[Egypt]]ian side and in the [[Gulf of Aqaba]], mangroves composed primarily of ''Avicennia marina'' and ''Rhizophora mucronata''<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ali A. Gab-Alla, Ishrak, K. Khafagi, Waleed, M. Morsy and Moustafa M. Fouda |date=2010 |title=Ecology of ''Avicennia marina'' mangals along Gulf of Aqaba, South Sinai, Red Sea |journal=Egypt J. Aquat. Biol. & Fish. |volume=14 |issue=2 |pages=79–93 |url=http://www.ejabf.eg.net/pdf/vol-14-n-2/6.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220051022/http://www.ejabf.eg.net/pdf/vol-14-n-2/6.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-02-20 |accessdate=25 January 2013 }}</ref> grow in about 28 stands that cover about 525 hectares.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}} Almost all Egyptian mangrove stands are now protected.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
There are mangroves off the east coast of [[South Africa]] extending as far south as the Tylomnqa River (33°13'26.1"S 27°34'50.2"E). Some mangrove stands exist in the [[St Lucia, KwaZulu-Natal|St Lucia]] [[estuary]] within [[iSimangaliso Wetland Park]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}
===Americas=== Mangroves live in many parts of the tropical and subtropical coastal zones of [[North America|North]] and [[South America]].
====Continental United States==== Because of their sensitivity to subfreezing temperatures, mangroves in the continental [[United States]] are limited to the [[Florida]] peninsula (see [[Florida mangroves]]) and some isolated growths<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nwrc.usgs.gov/climate/fs95_97.pdf |title="Modeling Hurricane Effects on Mangrove Ecosystems" U.S. Geological Survey, USGS FS-095-97, June 1997 |format=PDF |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref> of black mangrove (''[[Avicennia germinans]]'') at the southmost coast of [[Louisiana]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wlf.state.la.us/pdfs/experience/Coastal%20Mangrove-Marsh%20Shrubland.pdf |work=Conservation Habitats & Species Assessments |title=Coastal Mangrove-Marsh Shrubland |publisher=Louisiana Department of Wildlife & Fisheries |date=December 2005 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326171147/http://www.wlf.state.la.us/pdfs/experience/Coastal%20Mangrove-Marsh%20Shrubland.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-26 |df= }}</ref> and [[South Texas]].<ref>{{cite journal |first=Chenghai |last=Yang |author2=Everitt, James |author3=Fletcher, Reginald |author4=Jensen, Ryan |author5=Mausel, Paul |date=2008-03-15 |title=Mapping Black Mangrove Along the South Texas Gulf Coast Using AISA+ Hyperspectral Imagery |journal=Biennial Workshop on Aerial Photography, Videography, and High Resolution Digital Imagery for Resource Assessment Proceedings |publisher=American Society for Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing |url=http://www.ars.usda.gov/research/publications/publications.htm?seq_no_115=213366}}</ref>
====Mexico==== In Mexico four species of mangrove predominate: ''[[Rhizophora mangle]], [[Laguncularia racemosa]], [[Avicennia germinans]]'' and ''[[Conocarpus erectus]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mangroves of Mexico |url=http://www.biodiversidad.gob.mx/v_ingles/ecosystems/mangroves/mangroves.html|publisher=Biodiversidad.gob.mx|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> During an inventory conducted by [[CONABIO]] between 2006 and 2008, 770,057 hectares of mangrove were counted.<ref name="BioMx1">{{cite web|title=Monitoring program|url=http://www.biodiversidad.gob.mx/v_ingles/ecosystems/mangroves/monitoringProgram.html|publisher=Biodiversidad.gob.mx|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> Of this total, 55% are located in the [[Yucatán Peninsula]].<ref name="BioMx1" />
Significant mangals include the [[Marismas Nacionales-San Blas mangroves]] found in [[Sinaloa]] and [[Nayarit]].
====Central America and Caribbean==== [[File:ShrimpFarming Honduras L7 1987-99.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|The same area in Honduras shown in 1987 (bottom) and 1999 showing the corresponding removal of mangrove swamps for shrimp farming.]]
Mangroves occur on the Pacific and Caribbean coasts of [[Belize]], [[Costa Rica]], [[El Salvador]], [[Guatemala]], [[Honduras]], [[Nicaragua]], and [[Panama]]. Mangroves can also be found in many of the [[Antilles]] including [[Puerto Rico]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Departamento de Recursos Naturales y Ambientales |title=Los Maglares – Hojas de Nuestro Ambiente |url=http://www.drna.gobierno.pr/biblioteca/publicaciones/hojas-de-nuestro-ambiente/37%20Manglares.pdf |website=www.drna.gobierno.pr |publisher=Departamento de Recursos Naturales y Ambientales |accessdate=8 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609024218/http://www.drna.gobierno.pr/biblioteca/publicaciones/hojas-de-nuestro-ambiente/37%20Manglares.pdf |archivedate=9 June 2015 |df= }}</ref> [[Cuba]], and [[Hispaniola]],<ref>{{cite journal|last=Meyer-Arendt|first=Klaus|author2=Byrd. S |author3=Hamilton, SE |title=Mangrove deforestation in the Dominican Republic, 1969 to 2012|journal=GLOMIS / ISME Electronic Journal|date=October 2013 |volume=1|issue=1|page=1|url=http://www.glomis.com/ej/pdf/EJ_11-1.pdf|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> as well as other islands in the [[West Indies]] such as [[the Bahamas]].<!-- An exhaustive list is not necessary in this article. -->
=====Belize===== The nation of [[Belize]] has the highest overall percentage of forest cover of any of the Central American countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biological-diversity.info/Downloads/Ecosystem%20Mapping.zip |title=Vreugdenhil, D., Meerman, J., Meyrat, A., Gómez, L. D., and D. J. Graham "Map of the Ecosystems of Central America: Final Report" World Bank, Washington, DC. 56 pp. |date=2002 |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> In terms of Belize's mangrove cover—which assumes the form not only of mangrove 'forest', but also of scrubs and savannas, among others<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/s0378-1127(02)00036-1 |title=The mangroves of Belize |journal=Forest Ecology and Management |volume=174 |pages=265 |year=2003 |last1=Murray |first1=M.R |last2=Zisman |first2=S.A |last3=Furley |first3=P.A |last4=Munro |first4=D.M |last5=Gibson |first5=J |last6=Ratter |first6=J |last7=Bridgewater |first7=S |last8=Minty |first8=C.D |last9=Place |first9=C.J }}</ref>—a 2010 satellite-based study of Belize's mangroves by the [[World Wildlife Fund]] (WWF) and the Water Center for the Humid Tropics of Latin America and the Caribbean found, in 2010, mangroves covered some 184,548 acres (74,684 hectares) or 3.4% of Belize's territory.<ref name="maps.cathalac.org"/>
In 1980, by contrast, mangrove cover stood at 188,417 acres (76,250 hectares)—also 3.4% of Belize's territory, although based on the work of mangrove researcher Simon Zisman,<ref>Zisman, S.A. 1998. "Sustainability or Status Quo: Elite Influence and the Political Ecology of Mangrove Exploitation in Belize." Doctoral dissertation, Department of Geography, University of Edinburgh. Edinburgh, Scotland.</ref> Belize's mangrove cover in 1980 was estimated to represent 98.7% of the precolonial extent of those ecosystems. Belize's mangrove cover in 2010 was thus estimated to represent 96.7% of the precolonial cover.<ref name="maps.cathalac.org">[http://maps.cathalac.org/Downloads/data/bz/bz_mangroves_1980-2010_highres.pdf Cherrington, E.A., Hernandez, B.E., Trejos, N.A., Smith, O.A., Anderson, E.R., Flores, A.I., and B.C. Garcia. 2010. "Identification of Threatened and Resilient Mangroves in the Belize Barrier Reef System." Technical report to the World Wildlife Fund. Water Center for the Humid Tropics of Latin America and the Caribbean (CATHALAC) / Regional Visualization & Monitoring System (SERVIR). 28 pp.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130731035556/http://maps.cathalac.org/Downloads/data/bz/bz_mangroves_1980-2010_highres.pdf |date=July 31, 2013 }}</ref> Assessing changes in Belize's mangrove cover over a 30-year period was possible because of Belize's participation in the Regional Visualization and Monitoring System, a regional observatory jointly implemented by CATHALAC, RCMRD, ICIMOD, NASA, USAID, and other partners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2010/oct/HQ_10-241_SERVIR_Himalaya.html |title=NASA – NASA, USAID Expand Web-Based Environmental Monitoring System |publisher=Nasa.gov |date=2010-10-05 |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
====South America==== [[Brazil]] contains approximately 26,000 km<sup>2</sup> of mangals, 15% of the world's total.
Ecuador has substantial remaining mangrove forests in the provinces of El Oro, Guayas, Manabi and Esmeraldas with limited forest remaining in Santa Elena.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart|title=The impact of shrimp farming on mangrove ecosystems and local livelihoods along the Pacific coast of Ecuador|date=2011|publisher=ProQuest, UMI Dissertation Publishing|isbn=1249871735|page=194|url= https://www.researchgate.net/publication/257138926_The_Impact_of_Shrimp_Farming_on_Mangrove_Ecosystems_and_Local_Livelihoods_along_the_Pacific_Coast_of_Ecuador}}</ref> The northern portion of Esmeraldas province has a large pristine mangrove forest that is preserved as the Reserva Ecológica Cayapas-Mataje (REMACAN) and is an original Ramsar site.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ramsar sites Database|url=http://www.wetlands.org/RSIS/_COP9Directory/Directory/6EC011.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130416025735/http://www.wetlands.org/RSIS/_COP9Directory/Directory/6EC011.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-04-16|publisher=The Ramsar convention on wetlands}}</ref> This forest is the most preserved within Ecuador and likely the most pristine forest along the Pacific Coast of the Americas.<ref name="Hamilton 2012 177–202">{{cite journal|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart|author2=Clare Stankwitz|title=Examining the relationship between international aid and mangrove deforestation in coastal Ecuador from 1970 to 2006|journal=Land Use Science|date=2012|volume=7|issue=2|pages=177–202|doi=10.1080/1747423x.2010.550694 }}</ref> [[File:Via Mangue em construção - Recife, Pernambuco, Brasil.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|[[Recife]] in [[Brazil]], nicknamed the "Manguetown", has the largest urban mangrove forest in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anpec.org.br/revista/vol8/vol8n4p75_95.pdf|title=O Valor da Opção de Preservação do Parque dos Manguezais em Recife-PE: Uma Utilização do Método de Opções Reais|language=portuguese|publisher=ANPEC|accessdate=2015-06-04}}</ref>]] The only other major mangrove holding in Esmeraldas is in-and-around the community of Muisne and the Rio Muisne Estuary Swampland Wildlife Refuges.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ecuador:Mangrove Restoration in Muisne|url=http://www.globalrestorationnetwork.org/database/case-study/?id=50|publisher=Global Restoration Network|accessdate=20 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511062953/http://www.globalrestorationnetwork.org/database/case-study/?id=50|archive-date=2013-05-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The mangroves in-and-around the estuaries of Muisne have decreased in area from 3222 ha in 1971 to 1065 ha as of 2005, during this time commercial shrimp aquaculture has become the dominant land-cover within this estuary environment.<ref name="Hamilton 1–3">{{cite journal|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart|title=Quantifying mangrove deforestation in Ecuador's northern estuaries since the advent of commercial aquaculture|journal=Glomis / Isme|date=2011-01-01|volume=9|issue=1|pages=1–3|url=http://www.glomis.com/ej/index.html|accessdate=20 December 2012}}</ref>
On the border of Esmeraldas province and Manabí province is a formerly large area of mangrove within Cojimies Estuary. The mangroves in this estuary are some of the most degraded in Ecuador with only 19% of 1971 mangrove area remaining as of 1998, although mangrove has recovered since this date.<ref name="Hamilton 2012 177–202"/> Within Manabí the major mangrove holding estuary is the Chone estuary situated near the city of Bahía de Caráquez. Again, Chone has undergone substantial mangrove deforestation since the advent of commercial aquaculture in Ecuador.<ref name="Hamilton 1–3"/> Although mangrove loss appears to have halted in this estuary and mangrove regrowth driven by local fisherman is now occurring.<ref name="mingaonline.uach.cl">Hamilton, S. & S. Collins (2013) [http://mingaonline.uach.cl/scielo.php?script=sci_pdf&pid=S0717-92002013000200003&lng=es&nrm=iso&tlng=en Las respuestas a los medios de subsistencia deforestación de los manglares en las provincias del norte de Ecuador]. Bosque 34:2</ref>
Peru has a very small region of mangrove located in the north-west of the country on the Ecuadorian Border.<ref name="Giri2010" />
[[Venezuela]]'s northern Caribbean island, [[Isla Margarita|Margarita]], possesses mangrove forests in the [[Laguna de la Restinga|Parque nacional Laguna de La Restinga]]. Venezuela has 4% of the world's mangroves, with an extension of 6735 km<sup>2</sup>.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azulambientalistas.org/manglaresenvenezuela.html |title=Mangroves of Venezuela |publisher=azulambientalistas.org |accessdate=2012-12-13}}</ref>
[[Colombia]] possesses large mangrove forests on both its Caribbean and Pacific coasts.
The Mangrove forests of [[Suriname]] have a height of 20–25 m and are found mainly in the coastal area. There are six types of mangroves, namely two types of parwa or black mangroves, three types of red mangroves (mangro) and a small mangrove species (white mangrove, akira or tjila).<ref>Environmental statistics of Suriname 2014. http://www.statistics-suriname.org/index.php/statistieken/downloads/category/34-milieu-publicatie-2012</ref>
===Asia=== {{anchor|Bangladesch}}
====Sundarbans==== {{main|Sundarbans}} {{multiple image |perrow=1 |image1=সুন্দরবনের মানচিত্র.svg |caption1=Map showing Sundarbans in [[Bay of Bengal]] |image2=FarmHouseSunderban.JPG |caption2=Farm among [[paddy fields]] in the Sundarbans}}
The Sundarbans in the [[Ganges]]-[[Brahmaputra]] delta extend from the [[Hooghly River]] in [[West Bengal]] to the [[Baleswar River]] in [[Bangladesh]], covering an area of about {{convert|10000|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}. This area comprises closed and open mangrove forests, agriculturally used land, [[mudflat]]s and barren land. It is intersected by [[tidal]] streams and channels. Four protected areas in the Sundarbans, viz [[Sundarbans National Park]], [[Sundarbans West Wildlife Sanctuary|Sundarbans West]], [[Sundarbans South Wildlife Sanctuary|Sundarbans South]] and [[Sundarbans East Wildlife Sanctuary|Sundarbans East]] Wildlife Sanctuaries are enlisted as [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]s. [[Biodiversity]] includes at least 27 mangrove species, 40 mammal, 35 reptile and 260 bird species. More than 2.5 million people are estimated to live in the vicinity of the Sundarbans, making them one of the world's most densely populated areas.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Giri, C., Pengra, B., Zhu, Z., Singh, A. and Tieszen, L. L. |year=2007 |title=Monitoring mangrove forest dynamics of the Sundarbans in Bangladesh and India using multi-temporal satellite data from 1973 to 2000 |journal=Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science |volume=73 |issue=1−2 |pages=91−100 |doi=10.1016/j.ecss.2006.12.019}}</ref>
{{unreferenced section|date=November 2018}} It is the largest mangroves region and the largest single block of tidal halophytic mangrove forest in the world. Sundri (''[[Heritiera fomes]]'') trees provide durable hard timber. Palm, coconut, keora, agar, also grow in some parts of the delta. India's mangrove forests are habitat for [[saltwater crocodile]] (''Crocodylus porosus''), turtles, and snakes. This region is part of the Great Sundarbans and covers a National Park, Tiger reserve and a Biosphere Reserve.<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_wetland">{{cite web|url=http://www.walkthroughindia.com/walkthroughs/top-5-largest-wetland-and-ramsar-sites-in-india/|title=Largest Wetland and Ramsar Sites in India|publisher=}}</ref> Sundarbans was designated a Ramsar site on May 21, 1992. The fertile soils of the delta have been subject to intensive human use for centuries, and the ecoregion has been mostly converted to intensive agriculture, with few enclaves of forest remaining. The remaining forests, together with the Sundarbans mangroves, are important habitat for the endangered tiger. Additionally, the Sundarbans serves a crucial function as a protective flood barrier for the millions of inhabitants in and around [[Kolkata]] against the result of cyclone activity. Sundarbans is home to many different species of birds, mammals, insects, reptiles and fish. It is estimated that there may be found more than 120 species of fish and over 260 species of birds and more than fifty species of reptiles and eight amphibians.
====India==== As per the ISFR 2017 report, the total area of mangrove cover of India is 4921 km<sup>2</sup>, (181 km<sup>2</sup> positively changed with respect to 2015 mangrove cover assessment) which contributes 3.3% to the global mangrove cover.<ref name="fsi.nic.in">http://fsi.nic.in/isfr2017/isfr-mangrove-cover-2017.pdf</ref> The deltas of the [[Ganges]], [[Mahanadi River Delta|Mahanadi]], [[Krishna River|Krishna]], [[Godavari River|Godavari]], and [[Kaveri]] rivers contain mangrove forests. Backwaters in Kerala have high density of mangrove forest on the shores.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://travel.manoramaonline.com/travel/getting-about-kerala/thrissur/2018/07/31/chettuva-in-thrissur-flaunting-kerala-mangrove-forest.html|title=Chettuva in Thrissur: Flaunting Kerala’s biggest mangrove forest|work=OnManorama|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref> Indian mangroves consist of 46 species (4 of which are natural hybrids) belonging to 22 genera and 14 families, representing about 57% of the world’s mangrove species.<ref>http://tai2.ntu.edu.tw/taiwania/pdf/tai.2016.61.224.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref>
The following table shows the prevalence of mangroves in the states of India and the total area covered by them in square kilometres.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mapsofindia.com/top-ten/geography/mangrove-forest.html|title=Top 10 Mangrove Forest in India|publisher=}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Rank !! States/UTs with highest mangrove cover in 2017 !! Total mangrove cover in km<sup>2</sup> in 2015 !! 2017<ref name="India State Forest Report, 2015">[http://India%20State%20Forest%20Report,%202015 India State Forest Report, 2015]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="fsi.nic.in"/> |- | 1 || West Bengal || 2,106 || 2114 |- | 2 || Gujarat || 1,107 || 1140 |- | 3 || Andaman And Nicobar Islands || 617 || 617 |- | 4 || Andhra Pradesh || 367 || 404 |- | 5 || Maharashtra || 222 || 304 |- | 6 || Odisha || 231 || 243 |- | 7 || Tamil Nadu || 47 || 49 |- | 8 || Goa || 26 || 26 |- | 9 || Kerala || 9 || 9 |- | 10 || Karnataka || 3 || 10 |}
===== Bhitarkanika mangroves ===== The [[Bhitarkanika]] mangroves form India’s second largest forest, located in the state of Odisha. Bhitarkanika is created by the two river deltas of Brahmani and Baitarani river and one of the important Ramsar Wetland in India. It is also the home of [[saltwater crocodile]]s and nesting [[olive ridley]] sea turtles.<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_wetland"/><ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest">{{cite web|url=http://www.walkthroughindia.com/walkthroughs/top-5-largest-mangrove-and-swamp-forest-in-india/|title=Top 5 Largest Mangrove And Swamp Forest in India|publisher=}}</ref>
===== Godavari-Krishna mangroves ===== The Godavari-Krishna mangroves lie in the delta of the [[Godavari]] and [[Krishna River|Krishna]] rivers in the state of [[Andhra Pradesh]]. Mangroves ecoregion is under protection for [[Calimere]] Wildlife and [[Pulicat Lake Bird Sanctuary]].<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest"/>
===== Pichavaram mangroves ===== [[File:Pichavaram 1.jpg|thumb|Pichavaram hosts the second largest mangrove forests in the world]] The [[Pichavaram]] mangroves are situated at Pichavaram near [[Chidambaram]] in the state of [[Tamil Nadu]]. Pichavaram ranks amongst one of the most exquisite scenic spots in Tamil Nadu and has many species of aquatic birds.<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest"/>
===== Mumbai mangroves ===== The [[megacity]] [[Mumbai]] has mangroves on its coastline along the west coast of India. A total of 10 mangrove species were reported in this area, domiated by ''Avicennia marina''.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.rsma.2018.02.011 |title=Vegetative structure and species composition of mangroves along the Mumbai coast, Maharashtra, India |journal=Regional Studies in Marine Science |volume=19 |pages=1 |year=2018 |last1=Kantharajan |first1=G |last2=Pandey |first2=P.K |last3=Krishnan |first3=P |last4=Ragavan |first4=P |last5=Jeevamani |first5=J. Joyson Joe |last6=Purvaja |first6=R |last7=Ramesh |first7=R }}</ref> These mangroves support a rich diversity of life forms, especially molluscs.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.rsma.2017.06.002 |title=Molluscan diversity in the mangrove ecosystem of Mumbai, west coast of India |journal=Regional Studies in Marine Science |volume=14 |pages=102–11 |year=2017 |last1=Kantharajan |first1=G |last2=Pandey |first2=P.K |last3=Krishnan |first3=P |last4=Deepak Samuel |first4=V |last5=Bharti |first5=V.S |last6=Purvaja |first6=R }}</ref> The total mangrove area in Mumbai is 50 km<sup>2</sup>.<ref name="India State Forest Report, 2015"/> Mumbai's single largest mangrove belt is the western bank of [[Thane Creek]]. An extensive area of mangroves has been conserved by Soonabai Pirojsha Godrej Marine Ecology Centre, Vikhroli, Mumbai.<ref>http://www.mangroves.godrej.com/{{full citation needed|date=December 2017}}</ref>
===== Baratang Island mangroves ===== The [[Baratang Island]] mangroves are located within the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]]. The mangrove swamps of Baratang Island are situated between [[Middle Andaman Island|Middle]] and [[South Andaman Island]].<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest"/>
====Indo-Malaya Ecozone==== Mangroves occur on Asia's south coast, throughout the Indian subcontinent, in all [[Southeast Asia]]n countries, and on islands in the Indian Ocean, [[Persian gulf]], [[Arabian Sea]], [[Bay of Bengal]], [[South China Sea]], [[East China Sea]] and the Pacific.
The mangal is particularly prevalent in the deltas of large Asian rivers. The [[Sundarbans]] is the largest mangrove forest in the world, located in the Ganges River delta in [[Bangladesh]] and [[West Bengal]], [[India]].
The Pichavaram mangroves in [[Tamil Nadu]] is India's one of the largest mangrove forests. The [[Bhitarkanika Mangroves]] Forest of Odisha, by the Bay of Bengal, is India's second largest mangrove forest.{{Citation needed|reason=claim|date=September 2014}} Other major mangals occur on the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]] and the [[Gulf of Kutch]] in Gujarat.<ref>[http://www.mangroveindia.org/ Mangroves of India] – URL retrieved November 26, 2006</ref>
Mangroves occur in certain muddy swampy islands of the [[Maldives]].<ref>[[Xavier Romero-Frias]], ''The Maldive Islanders, A Study of the Popular Culture of an Ancient Ocean Kingdom''. Barcelona 1999, {{ISBN|84-7254-801-5}}.{{page needed|date=December 2017}}</ref>
On the [[Malayan Peninsula]] mangroves cover an estimated {{Convert|1089.7|sqkm|sqmi|1}}, while most of the remaining {{Convert|5320|sqkm|sqmi|0}} mangroves in [[Malaysia]] are on the [[Borneo|island of Borneo]].<ref>{{Cite news|author=Augustin, Sean|date=15 September 2014|title=Mangroves protect Malaysia’s coast, but also shield illegals|newspaper=The Rakyat Post|location=Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia|url=http://www.therakyatpost.com/news/2014/09/15/mangroves-protect-malaysias-coast-also-shield-illegals/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915011230/http://www.therakyatpost.com/news/2014/09/15/mangroves-protect-malaysias-coast-also-shield-illegals/|archivedate=15 September 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
In [[Vietnam]], mangrove forests grow along the southern coast, including two forests: the [[Can Gio Mangrove Forest]] [[biosphere reserve]] and the [[U Minh Thuong National Park|U Minh mangrove forest]] in the sea and coastal region of [[Kiên Giang Province|Kiên Giang]], [[Cà Mau Province|Cà Mau]] and [[Bạc Liêu Province|Bạc Liêu]] provinces.
The mangrove forests of Kompong Sammaki in [[Cambodia]] are of major ecological and cultural importance, as the human population relies heavily on the crabs and fish that live in the roots.
The three most important mangrove forests of [[Taiwan]] are: [[Tamsui River]] in Taipei, Jhonggang River in Miaoli and the [[Sihcao Wetlands]] in [[Tainan]]. According to research, four main types of mangrove exist in Taiwan.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fan |first1=K.C. |title=Mangroves in Taiwan: current status and restoration projects. |url=http://bft.cirad.fr/cd/BFT_273_43-54.pdf}}</ref> Some places have been developed as scenic areas, such as the [[Timber rafting|log raft]] routes in Sihcao.
The most extensive mangrove forests of the [[Ryukyu Islands]] in East China Sea occur on [[Iriomote Island]] of the [[Yaeyama Islands]], [[Okinawa]], [[Japan]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Nakasuga, Tsuneo | title = Analysis of the mangrove stand (Department of Forestry) |url = http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110000220076 |publisher = University of the Ryukyus |accessdate = 2015-08-19 }}</ref> Seven types of mangroves are recognised on Iriomote Island.<ref>{{cite web |title = Iriomote Island and the Iriomote Wildcat |url = http://web-japan.org/atlas/nature/nat22.html| publisher = Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) |accessdate = 2015-08-19 }}</ref>
The northern limit of mangrove forests in the Indo-Malaya ecozone is considered to be [[Tanegashima Island]], [[Kyushu]], Japan.<ref>{{cite web |author=Somiya, Kazuo |title = Conservation of landscape and culture in southwestern islands of Japan |format=PDF |url = http://acoms.kisti.re.kr/notReviewEpaperFile.do?method=finalDown&journalSeq=J000028&issueSeq=351&serviceEpaperSeq=1649 | publisher = Naha Nature Conservation Office, Ministry of the Environment | accessdate = 2015-08-19 }}</ref>
=====Indonesia===== In the [[List of islands of Indonesia|Indonesian Archipelago]], mangroves occur around much of [[Western New Guinea|Papua province]], [[Sumatra]], [[Borneo]], [[Sulawesi]], [[Maluku Islands|Maluku]] and the surrounding islands. Further north, they are found along the coast of the [[Malay Peninsula]]. Indonesia has around 9.36 million hectares of mangrove forests, but 48% is categorized as 'moderately damaged' and 23% as 'badly damaged'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/08/07/71-indonesian-mangrove-forests-damaged-minister.html |title=71% of Indonesian mangrove forests damaged: minister |work=The Jakarta Post |accessdate=2012-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118061854/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/08/07/71-indonesian-mangrove-forests-damaged-minister.html |archivedate=2012-01-18 |df= }}</ref>
====Pakistan==== [[File:GWR 2013- Certificate.jpg|thumb|upright|The Guinness World Record certificate of achievement to Sindh Forest Department, Govt of Sindh, Pakistan]] Pakistani mangroves are located mainly along the [[Indus River Delta|delta]] of the [[Indus River]] (the [[Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea mangroves]] [[ecoregion]]). Major mangrove forests are found on the coastline of the provinces of [[Sindh]] and [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]].
In [[Karachi]], land reclamation projects have led to the cutting down of mangrove forests for commercial and urban development. On 22 June 2013, Sindh Forest Department, Govt. of Sindh, Pakistan, with the help of 300 local coastal volunteer planters set the Guinness World Record by planting 847,250 mangrove saplings at Kharo Chan, Thatta, Sindh, Pakistan in a little over 12 hours. This is the highest number of saplings planted within a day under the Guinness World Record category of "Maximum Number of Trees Planted in a Day".
Sindh Forest Department, Government of Sindh Mangrove has played pioneer role for the conservation and protection of the mangroves in the Indus Delta since late 1950s when it was handed over the areas. A breakthrough success is the re-introduction of ''[[Rhizophora mucronata]]'' into the Indus Delta, which had become extinct there. More recently, a threatened mangrove shrub, ''[[Ceriops tagal]]'', has also been successfully re-introduced. A third species, ''[[Aegiceras corniculatum]]'', is under trials at the nursery stage.
A gigantic initiative is under in the Sindh, Pakistan, to rehabilitate the degraded and blank mangrove mudflats. Since 2010 alone, around 55,000 Hectares of such area has been planted and rehabilitated. During this period, through concerted efforts and a rigorous conservation policy adopted by the Sindh Forest Department, Govt. of Sindh and the federal govt. a mangrove resource base of 150,000 plus Hectares has been created, with the support of local coastal communities. International organizations like IUCN and WWF are also playing critical role to support this initiative of the government. Other achievements include: (1) Declaring all the mangrove forests in the Indus Delta as Protected Forests in December 2010; Constitution of a Mangrove Conservation Committee at the provincial level which includes all stakeholders as members and overall awareness of the importance of mangroves and its ecosystem.<ref name="Mangrove Planting">{{cite news |url=http://pakagri.blogspot.com/2013/06/by-planting-750000-mangroves-pakistan.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130624220628/http://pakagri.blogspot.com/2013/06/by-planting-750000-mangroves-pakistan.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 June 2013 | title=By planting 750,000 mangroves, Pakistan claims new world record. | date=22 June 2013 | publisher=[[Express Tribune]] |accessdate=23 June 2013}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="110px"> File:Newly planted mangroves.jpg|Shah Bundar, Sujawal, Pakistan, new mangrove plantation File:Young mangrove plantation in the Indus Delta.jpg|A young mangrove plantation in the Indus Delta File:Mangroves along Karachi Coast.jpg|Flourishing mangroves along Karachi coast, Pakistan File:Mangrove-Keti Bundar.jpg|Glowing mangrove plantation at Keti Bundar, Thatta, Pakistan </gallery>
====Iran==== Mangrove forests are present in [[Iran]] between 25°11′N to 27°52′N, in the northern parts of the [[Persian Gulf]] and [[Sea of Oman]]. Pockets of the biome extend (from southwest to southeast) along the shores of the maritime provinces [[Bushehr]], [[Hormozgan]], and [[Sistan and Balouchestan]].
Forests on and near the island of [[Qeshm]] in the Persian Gulf are dominated by the species ''[[Avicennia marina]]'', known locally as the "hara" or "harra" tree, and cover an area of approximately 20 km by 20 km. This area is protected as the UNESCO [[Mangrove forests of Qeshm|Hara Biosphere Reserve]], where commercial use is restricted to fishing (mainly [[shrimp]]), tourist boat trips, and limited mangrove cutting for animal feed.
====Middle East==== Oman, near Muscat, supports large areas of mangroves, in particular at Shinas, Qurm Park and Mahout Island. In Arabic, mangrove trees are known as ''qurm'', thus the mangrove area in Oman is known as Qurm Park. A small mangrove area is present in the Kingdom of Bahrain. Mangroves are also present extensively in neighbouring Yemen.<ref>Rouphael, Tony ;Turak, Emre and Brodie, Jon (1992) [https://web.archive.org/web/20090919204110/http://www.actfr.jcu.edu.au/idc/groups/public/documents/journal_article/jcudev_015628.pdf "Chapter 3: Seagrasses and Mangroves of Yemen's Red Sea"] In DouAbal, A. et al. (editors) (1992) ''Protection of Marine Ecosystems of the Red Sea Coast of Yemen'' Global Environment Facility, United Nations Development Programme, New York, pp. 41–49</ref>
Mangrove is also widely seen in Tarut Island, east of Qatif in Saudi Arabia. In addition, large forest of mangrove surround the coast to the south of Qatif (Siahat Beach). Nonetheless, because of sea land re-claiming the mangrove is being cut down which makes lots of sea fish losses their natural habitats.
The mangrove forests that cover thousands of hectares of land along the UAE shoreline form an integral part of its coastal ecosystem. The [[Environment Agency Abu Dhabi|Environment Agency – Abu Dhabi (EAD)]] is currently working on rehabilitation, conservation and protection of mangrove forests in seven key sites in Abu Dhabi including: Saadiyat Island, Jubail Island, Marawah Marine Biosphere Reserve (which also comprises famous Bu Tinah Island), Bu Syayeef Protected Area, Ras Gharab, the Eastern Corniche and Ras Ghanada.
===Oceania=== ====Australia and New Guinea==== {{main|Australian mangroves}} Australia and Papua New Guinea both rank in the top five mangrove holding nations globally.<ref name="Hamilton 2018 497–520">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-73016-5_22|title=Threats to Mangrove Forests|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart E.|last2=Castellanos-Galindo|first2=Gustavo A.|last3=Millones-Mayer|first3=Marco|last4=Chen|first4=Mara|date=2018|publisher=Springer, Cham|isbn=9783319730158|series=Coastal Research Library|pages=497–520|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-73016-5_22}}</ref> More than five species of Rhizophoraceae grow in [[Australasia]],<ref name="FAO-2007">{{cite book|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) |year=2007 |title=The world's mangroves, 1980–2005: a thematic study in the framework of the Global Forest Resources Assessment 2005 (FAO forestry paper #153(FAO) Rome |url={{google books|plainurl=y|id=tLdlpOiuSmEC|page=37}} |page =37 |isbn=978-92-5-105856-5}}</ref> with particularly high biodiversity on the [[island of New Guinea]] and northern Australia.<ref name="FAO-2007"/>
As of 2012 Australia has slightly below 1 million ha of mangrove <ref name="Hamilton 2018 497–520"/> and Papua New Guinea has just under approximately 500,000 ha +- 12% (CI 0.9, n = 7) of mangrove.<ref name="Hamilton 2018 497–520"/>
====New Zealand==== [[New Zealand]] also has mangrove forests extending to around 38°S (similar to Australia's latitudinal limit): the southernmost examples are at [[Raglan, New Zealand|Raglan Harbour]] (37°48′S) on the west coast and Ohiwa Harbour (near [[Opotiki]], 38°00′S) on the east coast.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} ''[[Avicennia marina]] australasica'' is the only mangrove in New Zealand.
====Pacific islands==== Twenty-five species of mangrove are found on various Pacific islands, with extensive mangals on some islands. Mangals on [[Guam]], [[Palau]], [[Kosrae]] and [[Yap]] have been badly affected by development.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://biology.usgs.gov/s+t/SNT/noframe/pi179.htm |title=Hawaii and the Pacific Islands |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927144136/http://biology.usgs.gov/s%2Bt/SNT/noframe/pi179.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2006 |author=Lloyd L. Loope |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]}}</ref>
Mangroves are not native to [[Hawaii]], but the red mangrove, ''[[Rhizophora mangle]]'', and Oriental mangrove, ''[[Bruguiera sexangula]]'', have been introduced and are now [[Naturalisation (biology)|naturalized]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Allen, James A. |author2=Krauss, Ken W. |lastauthoramp=yes |date=2006 |title=Influence of propagule flotation longevity and light availability on establishment of introduced mangrove species in Hawai'i |journal=[[Pacific Science]] |volume=60 |issue=3 |pages=367–376 |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/pacific_science/toc/psc60.3.html |doi=10.1353/psc.2006.0015 |hdl=10125/22572}}</ref> Both species are considered [[invasive species]] and classified as pests by the [[University of Hawaii]] Botany Department.<ref>[http://www.botany.hawaii.edu/faculty/cw_smith/aliens.htm Hawaiian Alien Plant Studies] – URL retrieved November 28, 2006.</ref>
==Mangroves around the world== <gallery widths="150px" heights="120px" class="center"> File:Mangrove park.JPG|Mangrove Park in [[Kannur]], India File:Sihcao Green Tunnel.JPG|Sihcao, [[Tainan]], [[Taiwan]] File:Mangrove knees Yap.jpg|[[Yap]], Micronesia File:Pichavaram mangrove forest panorama.jpg|[[Pichavaram]], India File:Mangrove swamp, Iriomote Island, Okinawa, Japan.jpg|[[Iriomote Island]], Japan </gallery>
==Exploitation and conservation== [[Image:Arrière-mangrove de Majicavo janvier 2017.jpg|thumb|Mangrove roots act as a net retaining waste and trash, hence accumulating pollution. Here in [[Mayotte]] at low tide.]] [[File:Bali Barat mangroves.jpg|thumb|Mangroves in [[West Bali National Park]], Indonesia.]]
Adequate data are only available for about half of the global area of mangroves. However, of those areas for which data has been collected, it appears that 35% of the mangroves have been destroyed.<ref>Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (2005) ''Ecosystems and Human Well-being: Synthesis'' (p.2) Island Press, Washington, DC. World Resources Institute {{ISBN|1-59726-040-1}}</ref> The [[United Nations Environment Programme]] and Hamilton (2013), estimate that [[shrimp farming]] causes approximately a quarter of the destruction of mangrove forests.<ref>Botkin, D. and E. Keller (2003) ''Environmental Science: Earth as a living planet'' (p.2) John Wiley & Sons. {{ISBN|0-471-38914-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.5343/bms.2012.1069 |title=Assessing the Role of Commercial Aquaculture in Displacing Mangrove Forest |journal=Bulletin of Marine Science |volume=89 |issue=2 |pages=585–601 |year=2013 |last1=Hamilton |first1=Stuart }}</ref> Likewise, the 2010 update of the World Mangrove Atlas indicated that approximately one fifth of the world's mangrove ecosystems have been lost since 1980,<ref name="nature.org">{{cite web|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100717013054/http://www.nature.org/pressroom/press/press4573.html|archive-date= 2010-07-17|url=http://www.nature.org/pressroom/press/press4573.html |title= 2010a. ""World Atlas of Mangroves" Highlights the Importance of and Threats to Mangroves: Mangroves among World's Most Valuable Ecosystems." Press release. Arlington, Virginia |publisher=The Nature Conservancy|accessdate=2014-01-25|deadurl= yes}}</ref> although this rapid loss rate appears to have decreased since 2000 with global losses estimated at between 0.16% and 0.39% annually between 2000 and 2012.<ref name=":2" /> Despite global loss rates decreasing since 2000, Southeast Asia remains an area of concern with loss rates between 3.58% and 8.08% between 2000 and 2012.<ref name=":2" />
Grassroots efforts to save mangroves from development are becoming more popular as their benefits become more widely known. In the [[Bahamas]], for example, active efforts to save mangroves are occurring on the islands of [[Bimini]] and [[Great Guana Cay]]. In [[Trinidad and Tobago]] as well, efforts are underway to protect a mangrove threatened by the construction of a steelmill and a port.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In Thailand, community management has been effective in restoring damaged mangroves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ecotippingpoints.org/our-stories/indepth/thailand-mangrove-restoration-community-management.html |title=Thailand – Trang Province – Taking Back the Mangroves with Community Management | The EcoTipping Points Project |publisher=Ecotippingpoints.org |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref> Within northern Ecuador mangrove regrowth is reported in almost all estuaries and stems primarily from local actors responding to earlier periods of deforestation in the Esmeraldas region.<ref name="mingaonline.uach.cl"/>
Mangroves have been reported to be able to help buffer against [[tsunami]], [[cyclone]]s, and other storms. One village in [[Tamil Nadu]] was protected from tsunami destruction—the villagers in [[Naluvedapathy]] planted 80,244 saplings to get into the [[Guinness Book of World Records]]. This created a kilometre-wide belt of trees of various varieties. When the tsunami struck, much of the land around the village was flooded, but the village itself suffered minimal damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treecouncil.org.uk |title=Tree News, Spring/Summer 2005, Publisher Felix Press |publisher=Treecouncil.org.uk |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
==Reforestation== [[File:Mangroves of Bohol.png|thumb|Mangroves in [[Bohol]], Philippines.]]
In some areas, mangrove reforestation and [[mangrove restoration]] is also underway. Red mangroves are the most common choice for cultivation, used particularly in [[marine aquariums]] in a [[sump]] to reduce [[nitrates]] and other [[nutrients]] in the water. Mangroves also appear in home [[aquariums]], and as ornamental plants, such as in [[Japan]].
In Senegal, [[Haïdar El Ali]] has started the {{Il|fr|Oceanium de Dakar}} project, which (amongst others) focuses on reforesting several areas with mangroves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oceanium.blogspot.com/ |title=Oceanium de Dakar |publisher=Oceanium.blogspot.com |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
The Manzanar Mangrove Initiative is an ongoing experiment in [[Arkiko]], [[Eritrea]], part of the Manzanar Project founded by [[Gordon H. Sato]], establishing new mangrove plantations on the coastal [[mudflat]]s. Initial plantings failed, but observation of the areas where mangroves did survive by themselves led to the conclusion that nutrients in water flow from inland were important to the health of the mangroves. Trials with the Eritrean Ministry of Fisheries followed, and a planting system was designed to provide the nitrogen, phosphorus, and iron missing from seawater.<ref name="NatGeo2007-02"/><ref name="SocWetlandSci"/>
The propagules are planted inside a reused galvanized steel can with the bottom knocked out; a small piece of iron and a pierced plastic bag with fertilizer containing nitrogen and phosphorus are buried with the propagule. {{As of|2007}}, after six years of planting, 700,000 mangroves are growing; providing stock feed for sheep and habitat for oysters, crabs, other bivalves, and fish.<ref name="NatGeo2007-02">{{cite web | last = Warne | first = Kennedy | others = Tim Laman, photographer | title = Mangroves: Forests of the Tide | work = National Geographic | publisher = National Geographic Society | date = February 2007 | url = http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2007/02/mangroves/warne-text/5 | accessdate = 2010-08-08}} </ref><ref name="SocWetlandSci">{{Cite journal | last = Sato | first = Gordon | authorlink = Gordon H. Sato | author2 = Abraham Fisseha |author3=Simon Gebrekiros |author4=Hassan Abdul Karim |author5=Samuel Negassi |author6=Martin Fischer |author7=Emanuel Yemane |author8=Johannes Teclemariam |author9=Robert Riley |lastauthoramp=yes | title = A novel approach to growing mangroves on the coastal mud flats of Eritrea with the potential for relieving regional poverty and hunger | journal = Wetlands | volume = 25 | issue = 3 | pages = 776–779 | doi = 10.1672/0277-5212(2005)025[0776:ANATGM]2.0.CO;2
| year = 2005 }}</ref>
==National studies== In terms of local and national studies of mangrove loss, the case of Belize's mangroves is illustrative in its contrast to the global picture. A recent, satellite-based study<ref name="maps.cathalac.org"/>—funded by the World Wildlife Fund and conducted by the Water Center for the Humid Tropics of Latin America and the Caribbean (CATHALAC)—indicates Belize's mangrove cover declined by a mere 2% over a 30-year period. The study was born out of the need to verify the popular conception that mangrove clearing in Belize was rampant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ambergriscaye.com/pages/town/art/Pelican_Review.pdf |title=Pelican_Cays_Review |format=PDF |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
Instead, the assessment showed, between 1980 and 2010, under {{convert|4,000|acre|km2}} of mangroves had been cleared, although clearing of mangroves near Belize's main coastal settlements (e.g. [[Belize City]] and San Pedro) was relatively high. The rate of loss of Belize's mangroves—at 0.07% per year between 1980 and 2010—was much lower than Belize's overall rate of forest clearing (0.6% per year in the same period).<ref>[http://www.servir.net/servir_bz_forest_cover_1980-2010.pdf Cherrington, E.A., Ek, E., Cho, P., Howell, B.F., Hernandez, B.E., Anderson, E.R., Flores, A.I., Garcia, B.C., Sempris, E., and D.E. Irwin. 2010. "Forest Cover and Deforestation in Belize: 1980–2010." Water Center for the Humid Tropics of Latin America and the Caribbean. Panama City, Panama. 42 pp.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729135101/http://www.servir.net/servir_bz_forest_cover_1980-2010.pdf |date=July 29, 2013 }}</ref> These findings can also be interpreted to indicate Belize's mangrove regulations (under the nation's)<ref>[http://www.belizelaw.org/lawadmin/PDF%20files/cap213s.pdf Government of Belize (GOB). 2003. "Forests Act Subsidiary Laws." Chapter 213 in: Substantive Laws of Belize. Revised Edition 2003. Government Printer: Belmopan, Belize. 137 pp.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313105434/http://www.belizelaw.org/lawadmin/PDF%20files/cap213s.pdf |date=March 13, 2012 }}</ref> have largely been effective. Nevertheless, the need to protect Belize's mangroves is imperative, as a 2009 study by the World Resources Institute (WRI) indicates the ecosystems contribute US$174–249 million per year to Belize's national economy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pdf.wri.org/working_papers/coastal_capital_belize_wp.pdf |title=Coastal Capital: Belize. The Economic Contribution of Belize's Coral Reefs and Mangroves |format=PDF |last1=Cooper |first1=E. |last2=Burke |first2=L. |last3=Bood |first3=N. |date=2009 |publisher=World Resources Institute |location=Washington, DC |accessdate=2014-06-23}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Wetlands}} * [[Mangrove swamp]] * [[Blue carbon]] * [[Ecological values of mangrove]] * [[Mangrove restoration]] * [[Salt marsh]]
